title: 111_hr4794
content: The Act titled "Safeguarding Access to Preventative Services Act of 2010" prohibits denial or restriction of coverage based on task force recommendations. The Act "Safeguarding Access to Preventative Services Act of 2010" prohibits using Preventive Services Task Force recommendations to deny or restrict coverage under Federal health care programs. In this subsection, definitions for terms like "group health plan" and "health insurance coverage" are provided based on specific sections of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Federal health care program" is defined according to a section of the Social Security Act. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act regarding group health plans and health insurance are also outlined. The Preventive Services Task Force recommendations cannot be used to deny or restrict coverage in group health plans or individual market health insurance. The provisions of section 2708 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, similar to coverage in connection with a group health plan. Amendments to ERISA include a new section prohibiting denial or restriction of coverage based on Task Force recommendations. The group health plan and health insurance issuer cannot deny or restrict coverage based on recommendations from the Preventive Services Task Force. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include a new section prohibiting coverage denial or restriction based on Task Force recommendations. Group health plans cannot deny or restrict coverage based on recommendations from the Preventive Services Task Force. This is outlined in a new section of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this subsection apply to plan years starting after the enactment of the Act. Coverage of preventive items and services in the group market is addressed in the Public Health Service Act. The Public Health Service Act addresses coverage of preventive items and services in the group market, as stated in SEC. 2709. The Public Health Service Act requires consultation with medical organizations to determine coverage of preventive items and services in group health plans. Guidelines must be disclosed to enrollees as part of a summary of benefits and coverage. The Public Health Service Act mandates consultation with medical organizations to determine coverage of preventive items and services in group health plans, with guidelines disclosed to enrollees as part of a summary of benefits and coverage. Individual market regulations are also amended to include this requirement. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 require health insurance issuers in the individual market to follow the same preventive items and services coverage provisions as those in the small or large group market. The plan sponsor and health insurance issuer must consult medical guidelines from professional organizations when determining coverage for preventive items and services. Guidelines related to women's preventive services must be disclosed to participants and beneficiaries. The plan sponsor and health insurance issuer must disclose guidelines and recommendations for preventive services to participants and beneficiaries as required under section 102. Failure to do so will be considered a violation of the section. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding a section on determinations of coverage of preventive items and services. The plan sponsor of a group health plan must consult medical guidelines from professional medical organizations when deciding on preventive items and services to cover. Guidelines related to women's preventive services must be disclosed to participants and beneficiaries. The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 100 of the Code is amended to include a new item after section 9813, related to disclosing guidelines for women's preventive services to participants and beneficiaries. The amendments in subsections (a)(1), (b), and (c) of this section apply to plan years starting after the enactment of the Act. The amendment in subsection (a)(2) applies to health insurance coverage in the individual market on or after that date.
